publicationstmt.publisher: Free Library of Philadelphia, Print and Picture Collection

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.repository: Free Library of Philadelphia, Print and Picture Collection

bioghist.p: Herbert Pullinger (1878-1961) was a life long resident of Philadelphia. He was a painter, printmaker, and commercial illustrator, as well as being a teacher at the Philadelphia Museum School of Industrial Arts (now the University of the Arts) from 1923 to 1958. He first studied art at the School of Industrial Arts, followed by the Drexel Institute, and finally enrolled at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts for studies with Henry McCarter and Thomas Anshutz. During the 1920s, he emerged as one of America's foremost wood engravers.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of etchings, aquatints, lithographs and lithographic pencil drawings, pen and ink drawings, woodcuts, pencil sketches and drawings, and watercolors by Herbert Pullinger. Most of the lithographs, woodcuts, and drawings in the collection are city views of Philadelphia, landscapes and riverscapes along the Wissahickon Creek, and bridges and historical houses in the Philadelphia area. A number of the watercolors are seaside images. There is a small batch of photomechanical reproductions of Pullinger's prints, including an unbound series of views of Philadelphia which were published in Philadelphia Past and Present in 1915 as well as a copy of the volume. The collection also includes watercolors by his wife, Frances Pullinger.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
